description: From Middle English above, aboven, abuven, from Old English ābufan, onbufan, from on (“on”) + bufan (“over”), (akin to Icelandic ofan (“from above”), Middle Dutch bōven, Old Frisian bova, Middle High German bobene) from bī (“by”) + ufan (“over”); also cognate with Danish oven, Dutch boven, German oben, Swedish ovan, Old Saxon oƀan, Old High German obana.
The preposition, adjective and the noun derive from the adverb.

entries.meaning: Of heaven; heavenly. [first attested around (1150 to 1350).]
(by ellipsis) Being located higher on the same page or on a preceding page. [first attested in the mid 18th century.]
Directly overhead; vertically on top of. [first attested before 1150.]
Higher in the same page; earlier in the order as far as writing products go. [first attested before 1150.]
Into or from heaven; in the sky. [first attested around 1150–1350]
examples: He's in a better place now, floating free as the clouds above.

entries.meaning: In a higher place; upstairs; farther upstream. [first attested around 1150–1350]
Higher in rank, power, or position. [first attested around 1150–1350]
examples: He appealed to the court above.

entries.meaning: (archaic) In addition. [first attested around 1150–1350]
More in number. [first attested around 1350–1470]
Above zero; above freezing. [first attested in the mid 20th century.]
examples: It was a cold day at only 5 above.

entries.meaning: (biology) On the upper half or the dorsal surface of an animal.
examples: The sparrow I saw was rufous above and off-white below.

entries.meaning: Heaven. [first attested around 1150–1350]
Something, especially a person's name in legal documents, that appears higher on the same page or on a preceding page.
Higher authority.
(archaic) betterment, raised status or condition.
Physically over; on top of; worn on top of, said of clothing. [first attested before 1150.]
examples: He always put his coat on above his sweater.

entries.meaning: In or to a higher place; higher than; on or over the upper surface. [first attested  before 1150]
Farther north than. [first attested before 1150]
Rising; appearing out of reach height-wise. [first attested around 1150–1350]

(figuratively) Higher than; superior to in any respect; surpassing; higher in measure, degree, volume, or pitch, etc. than; out of reach; not exposed to; not likely to be affected by; incapable of negative actions or thoughts. [first attested around 1150–1350]
examples: Even the chief of police is not above suspicion.
I thought you said you were above these kinds of antics.

entries.meaning: Higher in rank, status, or position. [first attested around 1150–1350]
examples: to stand head and shoulders above the rest

entries.meaning: (Scotland) In addition to; besides. [first attested around 1150–1350]
examples: above and beyond the call of duty

entries.meaning: Surpassing in number or quantity; more than. [first attested around 1350–1470]
examples: That amount is way above our asking price.

entries.meaning: In preference to.
Too proud to stoop to; averse to; disinclined towards;
examples: The owner was above taking more than a token salary.

entries.meaning: Beyond; on the other side.
(theater) Upstage of.
